quizTitle: O-Level Chemistry: Mole & Redox Calculations (Progressive Difficulty)
instructions: Answer the following questions in order of increasing difficulty. All necessary equations are provided. Assume molar volume at r.t.p. = 24 dm³/mol. Use atomic masses: H=1, C=12, N=14, O=16, Na=23, Mg=24, Al=27, S=32, Cl=35.5, K=39, Cr=52, Mn=55, Fe=56, Cu=64, Zn=65, Ag=108, Pb=207.

questions.question: A solution contains 0.1 mol of sodium sulfate (Na₂SO₄). When dissolved in water, how many moles of sodium ions (Na⁺) are produced?
questions.explanation: Na₂SO₄ → 2Na⁺ + SO₄²⁻. 0.1 mol Na₂SO₄ gives 0.2 mol Na⁺. This tests basic dissociation stoichiometry.

questions.question: A 0.1 mol sample of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) decomposes on heating: CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂. What mass of carbon dioxide is produced? (Ar: C=12, O=16)
questions.explanation: 1 mol CaCO₃ → 1 mol CO₂. 0.1 mol CO₂ formed. Mr(CO₂) = 44. Mass = 0.1 × 44 = 4.4 g. Single-step mass calculation.

questions.question: A solution contains 0.2 mol of aluminum sulfate, Al₂(SO₄)₃. When dissolved, what is the total number of moles of ions produced?
questions.explanation: Al₂(SO₄)₃ → 2Al³⁺ + 3SO₄²⁻. 1 mol compound → 5 mol ions. 0.2 mol → 1.0 mol ions. Requires counting multiple ion types.

questions.question: When 0.1 mol of silver nitrate (AgNO₃) reacts with excess sodium chloride, AgNO₃ + NaCl → AgCl + NaNO₃, what mass of silver chloride precipitate (Mr=143.5) forms?
questions.explanation: 1:1 ratio → 0.1 mol AgCl formed. Mass = 0.1 × 143.5 = 14.35 g. Straightforward single-reaction precipitation.

questions.question: When chlorine gas is passed into hot concentrated sodium hydroxide: 3Cl₂ + 6NaOH → 5NaCl + NaClO₃ + 3H₂O. If 0.3 mol of Cl₂ reacts completely, how many moles of NaCl are produced?
questions.explanation: 3 mol Cl₂ → 5 mol NaCl. 0.3 mol Cl₂ → (5/3)×0.3 = 0.5 mol NaCl. Introduces non-1:1 stoichiometric ratios.

questions.question: A solution contains 0.1 mol of sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄). It is neutralized with sodium hydroxide: H₂SO₄ + 2NaOH → Na₂SO₄ + 2H₂O. The sodium sulfate produced is then reacted with barium chloride: Na₂SO₄ + BaCl₂ → BaSO₄ + 2NaCl. What mass of barium sulfate (Mr=233) precipitate forms?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: 0.1 mol H₂SO₄ → 0.1 mol Na₂SO₄.
Step 2: 0.1 mol Na₂SO₄ → 0.1 mol BaSO₄.
Mass = 0.1 × 233 = 23.3 g. First two-step sequential reaction.

questions.question: When 0.1 mol of potassium permanganate (KMnO₄) reacts completely with acidified iron(II) sulfate: 2KMnO₄ + 10FeSO₄ + 8H₂SO₄ → 2MnSO₄ + 5Fe₂(SO₄)₃ + K₂SO₄ + 8H₂O. How many moles of Fe²⁺ ions are oxidized?
questions.explanation:
2 mol KMnO₄ oxidizes 10 mol Fe²⁺ → 1 mol KMnO₄ oxidizes 5 mol Fe²⁺.
0.1 mol KMnO₄ oxidizes 0.5 mol Fe²⁺. Introduces redox stoichiometry with electron transfer concepts.

questions.question: When 1.2 g of magnesium ribbon (Mg) reacts with excess hydrochloric acid, Mg + 2HCl → MgCl₂ + H₂, the hydrogen gas produced is collected. This hydrogen is then reacted with 6.4 g of copper(II) oxide, CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O. What mass of copper is produced?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Moles Mg = 1.2 ÷ 24 = 0.05 mol → 0.05 mol H₂.
Step 2: Moles CuO = 6.4 ÷ 80 = 0.08 mol.
H₂ limiting (0.05 < 0.08) → 0.05 mol Cu formed.
Mass Cu = 0.05 × 64 = 3.2 g. First limiting reactant problem.

questions.question: A solution contains 0.3 mol of barium chloride (BaCl₂) and 0.2 mol of sodium sulfate (Na₂SO₄). When mixed, BaCl₂ + Na₂SO₄ → BaSO₄ + 2NaCl. What mass of barium sulfate precipitate (Mr=233) forms, and which ions remain in solution?
questions.explanation:
Na₂SO₄ limiting (0.2 mol) → 0.2 mol BaSO₄ formed.
Mass = 0.2 × 233 = 46.6 g.
Excess Ba²⁺ (0.1 mol) remains with Na⁺ (0.4 mol) and Cl⁻ (0.6 mol). Combines limiting reactant with ion analysis.

questions.question: When 0.2 mol of sodium peroxide (Na₂O₂) reacts with water: 2Na₂O₂ + 2H₂O → 4NaOH + O₂, and the oxygen produced reacts with sulfur: S + O₂ → SO₂, what maximum mass of sulfur dioxide (Mr=64) can be formed?
questions.explanation:
2 mol Na₂O₂ → 1 mol O₂ → 0.2 mol Na₂O₂ → 0.1 mol O₂.
1 mol O₂ → 1 mol SO₂ → 0.1 mol SO₂ formed.
Mass = 0.1 × 64 = 6.4 g. Two sequential reactions with gas intermediate.

questions.question: When 4.8 g of magnesium reacts with excess sulfuric acid, Mg + H₂SO₄ → MgSO₄ + H₂, and the hydrogen produced reduces 16.0 g of copper(II) oxide, CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O, what is the limiting reactant in the second reaction?
questions.explanation:
Moles Mg = 4.8 ÷ 24 = 0.2 mol → 0.2 mol H₂.
Moles CuO = 16.0 ÷ 80 = 0.2 mol.
1:1 ratio with equal moles → both react completely. Requires precise stoichiometric comparison.

questions.question: A 0.1 mol sample of iron(III) chloride (FeCl₃) is dissolved in water. Excess silver nitrate is added: FeCl₃ + 3AgNO₃ → 3AgCl + Fe(NO₃)₃. What mass of silver chloride (Mr=143.5) precipitate forms?
questions.explanation:
1 mol FeCl₃ → 3 mol AgCl. 0.1 mol FeCl₃ → 0.3 mol AgCl.
Mass = 0.3 × 143.5 = 43.05 g. Tests ability to handle 1:3 stoichiometric ratios with polyatomic ions.

questions.question: A 0.2 mol sample of ammonium nitrate (NH₄NO₃) decomposes: NH₄NO₃ → N₂O + 2H₂O. The nitrous oxide produced is decomposed further: 2N₂O → 2N₂ + O₂. What total volume of gases (N₂ + O₂) is produced at r.t.p.?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: 0.2 mol NH₄NO₃ → 0.2 mol N₂O.
Step 2: 2N₂O → 2N₂ + O₂ → 0.2 mol N₂O → 0.2 mol N₂ + 0.1 mol O₂ = 0.3 mol gases.
Volume = 0.3 × 24 = 7.2 dm³. Combines multi-step reactions with gas volume calculations.

questions.question: When 0.15 mol of lead(II) nitrate, Pb(NO₃)₂, is heated: 2Pb(NO₃)₂ → 2PbO + 4NO₂ + O₂. The nitrogen dioxide is dissolved in water: 3NO₂ + H₂O → 2HNO₃ + NO. How many moles of nitric acid (HNO₃) are produced?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: 2 mol Pb(NO₃)₂ → 4 mol NO₂ → 0.15 mol → 0.3 mol NO₂.
Step 2: 3 mol NO₂ → 2 mol HNO₃ → 0.3 mol NO₂ → 0.2 mol HNO₃.
Requires tracking intermediates across two unbalanced reaction sequences.

questions.question: When 0.267 mol of potassium chlorate (KClO₃) decomposes: 2KClO₃ → 2KCl + 3O₂, and the oxygen produced burns phosphorus: 4P + 5O₂ → 2P₂O₅, what mass of phosphorus(V) oxide (P₂O₅, Mr=142) is formed?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: 2 mol KClO₃ → 3 mol O₂ → 0.267 mol → 0.4005 mol O₂.
Step 2: 5 mol O₂ → 2 mol P₂O₅ → 0.4005 mol O₂ → 0.1602 mol P₂O₅.
Mass = 0.1602 × 142 ≈ 22.72 g. Most complex: fractional mole ratios across two reactions with precise arithmetic.
